entry.title: Re: Transfer posting 309 with structured article
entry.content: Hello JL23, Unfortunately, I don't have any experience in this area yet, but I currently have the following problem: We purchase an alcoholic mixed drink in cans, for which we have the drink in the can as a separate article and the deposit article as a separate article number in the parts list. When an order is placed, the article and the drink are created and the deposit article number is automatically added to the order. The same applies to goods receipt and goods issue postings. But now we have the issue that a customer wants to purchase this via a tax warehouse and this is exactly where the problem arises that the beverage article could be posted, but the deposit article cannot! Are there any tips on how other companies handle this? VG Norbert

entry.title: Bridging EDI and SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Seamless EDI-to-SOAP Integration
entry.content:
In the fast-paced world of business today, it's crucial to connect traditional EDI systems with modern cloud ERP systems for streamlined operations. This blog takes a closer look at an integration fllow that handles inbound EDI messages, transforms them into SOAP format and facilitate effortless communication with SAP S/4HANA Cloud. Let's explore how this approach changes data formats and guarantees a reliable,standards-complaint integration between legacy and cloud systems.

Note:  For detailed steps on creating and exporting the required MIG and MAG files used in this integration, please refer to the blog: Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor i... - SAP Community.

Step-by-Step Guide: EDI to SOAP Inbound Integration Flow

Here’s a detailed look at the entire integration flow (iFlow) for processing EDI to SOAP inbound messages. This iFlow covers all the essential steps and components needed to receive, validate, transform, and route EDI messages into SOAP format, ensuring a smooth connection to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.

Step 1: Receive EDI Data via AS2

To initiate the integration, configure the AS2 adapter to receive inbound EDI messages. This configuration supports secure and reliable data transfer in B2B scenarios involving EDI communication.

Note: For detailed steps on setting up the AS2 adapter, refer to the blog: Step-by-Step Guide: Secure File Exchange with AS2 Adapter in SAP Cloud Integration – SAP Community

Step 2: Add Start Message

Add a Start Message event to initiate the integration flow when EDI data is received through AS2.

Step 3: Add EDI Splitter

Add an EDI Splitter for handling incoming EDI messages. It breaks them down into individual transactions, checks their structure for validity, and can also generate acknowledgments if necessary.

Important:All the XSD and mapping files mentioned in this flow( ASC-X12 XSD, preproc.xsl, and others)—are created and exported during the MIG and MAG setup process in SAP Integration Advisor.
For a step-by-step guide on generating and exporting these files, please refer to the blog: Creating MIGs and MAGs Using Integration Advisor i... - SAP Community.

  • Upload ASC-X12 XSD File
  1. To upload ASC-X12 XSD file, navigate to the X12 tab in the EDI Splitter configuration. You’ll find the file in the Source folder that was extracted during the MAG export.
  2. This file outlines the structure of the incoming EDI message, allowing the splitter to accurately parse and process the X12 message.

Step 4: Add Router

Now, let’s add a Router following the EDI Splitter. This step is crucial for separating EDI messages from acknowledgement messages, especially if you’ve enabled the generation of acknowledgements in the splitter.

Let's define two routing paths:

1. Acknowledgement Route: This route deals with acknowledgement messages independently.

In the Processing tab, you’ll see:

Expression Type Options:

  • XML: This is used when the message is formatted in XML.
  • NON_XML: This is for messages that aren’t in XML format, where routing is based on the message headers.

We opt for NON_XML since the acknowledgement message isn’t in XML, so the router checks the message headers instead of the XML content.

 Condition: ${header.EDI_ACKNOWLEDGEMENT} = 'true'

 

2. Default Route: Responsible for processing standard EDI messages.

No condition needed (processes all other messages)

Step 5: Integrate EDI to XML Converter

Now, let’s add an EDI to XML Converter to convert the EDI message into XML format.

  • Upload ASC-X12 XSD File

  1. Navigate to the X12 tab and upload the ASC-X12.xsd file from the Source folder that you got from the MAG export.
  2. The ASC-X12 XSD file defines the structure of the incoming EDI message, enabling the EDI to XML Converter to accurately interpret and transform the EDI data into XML format.

Step 6: Include XSLT Mapping (Pre-processing)

Next up, we’ll add XSLT Mapping to handle data preprocessing and transformation.

  • Upload preproc.xsl File
  1. Under the Processing tab, upload the preproc.xsl File from the Source folder extracted from the MAG export.
  2.  This step modifies the XML structure created from the EDI message, ensuring it aligns with the expected input format for message mapping.

Step 7: Add XML Validator (Post-processing)

Add an XML Validator to validate the pre-processed XML.

  • Upload X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_RD.xsd File
  1. Navigate to the Validation tab and upload the X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_RD.xsd file from the Source folder you extracted from the MAG export.
  2. This step makes sure that the transformed XML adheres to the expected schema before you proceed to message mapping, helping you identify any structural issues early on.

Step 8: Implement XSLT Mapping (Main Mapping)

Let’s add an XSLT Mapping to transform the validated EDI XML into the target SOAP message structure.

  • Upload Mapping_X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_to_SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG.xsl File

  1. Under the Processing tab, you’ll need to upload the Mapping_X12_850_PurchaseOrder_MIG_to_SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG.xsl file from the root folder of the exported MAG zip file.
  2. This main mapping file, which was generated by SAP Integration Advisor (IA), is crucial for transforming the data into the right format for SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

Step 9: Apply XSLT Mapping (Post-processing)

Add an XSLT Mapping to adjust the mapped XML output to the final structure required by the target system.

  • Upload SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG_postproc.xsl File
  1. Head over to the Processing tab and upload the SOAP_SalesOrder_MIG_postproc.xsl file from the Target MIG folder.
  2. This ensures the transformed XML matches the exact format expected by the target system for successful processing.

Step 10: Add SOAP Receiver Adapter

Use the SOAP Receiver Adapter to connect to SAP S/4HANA and transmit the transformed XML payload over a SOAP-based web service. This adapter ensures that the data is encapsulated in a SOAP envelope and sent to the appropriate endpoint.

  • Address:Enter the SOAP service endpoint URL provided by your target system.

  • URL to WSDL:Click on Browse and upload the .wsdl file that corresponds to your target SOAP service. CPI will automatically fill in the Service, Endpoint, and Operation Name fields based on the WSDL information.
  • Authentication: Basic
  • Credential Name: Enter the Credential Name of the User Credentials you set up in Security Material.

This marks the end of the configuration for the EDI-to-SOAP inbound integration flow. With this iFlow in action, incoming EDI messages are handled efficiently and routed to the S/4HANA target system in the required SOAP format.

Disclaimer:
All the views and opinions in this blog are my own and are made in my personal capacity. SAP shall not be responsible or liable for any of the contents published in this blog.

entry.title: Implementing Data Flows in SAP Datasphere: Concepts and Examples
entry.content:
Understanding Data Flows in SAP Datasphere

Introduction

In SAP Datasphere, flows are a key component for implementing ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) and ELT (Extract, Load, Transform) processes. We can think of Data flow as traditional ETL pipelines whereas Replication flow aligns more closely with modern data engineering practices where raw data is replicated or ingested into the data lakes and then transformation logic is applied afterwards which aligns with transformation flow. Below are the three types of flows available.

  1. Data Flow
  2. Replication Flow
  3. Transformation Flow

In this blog post, we’ll focus on the end to end functionalities in Data Flow — covering the below areas.

  1. What is Data Flow?
  2. Why Use a Data Flow?
  3. Data flow Comparison with Replication and Transformation flows.
  4. Data load modes for target tables.
  5. How to create a Data Flow?
  6. How to use Custom Python script in Data Flow?
  7. How to use input parameters in Data Flow?
  8. How to schedule the Data Flow?

What Is a Data Flow in SAP Datasphere?

A Data Flow in SAP Datasphere is used to integrate and transform data from both SAP and non-SAP sources, and move it between various targets within the Datasphere environment.

It supports:

- Standard transformation operations: filter, join, union, aggregation

- Advanced operations using Python scripts

- Batch processing workloads

It’s comparable to SAP BODS or Process Chains in SAP BW.

Source Compatibility:

Data Flows are supported for most sources currently integrated with Datasphere, including:

- SAP S/4HANA CDS views

- SLT (SAP Landscape Transformation)

- Non-SAP sources like Amazon Redshift, Google BigQuery, and Azure Data Lake

However, they do not support:

- ODP-based data sources (e.g., classic BW extractors)

- SAP BW/4HANA 

- Amazon Athena

For delta extraction from S/4HANA, you must use delta-enabled CDS views.

Why Use a Data Flow?

- To bring data into SAP Datasphere from various sources

- To perform complex transformations (e.g., business logic, calculations)

- To persist intermediate or final datasets within different layers (e.g., raw, harmonized, consumption)

Data Flow vs Replication Flow vs Transformation Flow

Here is a quick comparison between 3 flows based on their use cases.

Flow Type

Primary Use Case

Transformation

Notes

Data Flow

ETL

Yes

Transform and load

Replication Flow

ELT

No

Just extracts and loads

Transformation Flow

Post-load transforms

Yes

Works on already loaded data

Data Load Modes for Target Tables

When loading data to a target table in a Data Flow, you can choose from three update modes:

 

1. Append

- Inserts all incoming records as new rows

- Does not affect existing data

- Use Case: Incremental/historical loads

2. Truncate

- Deletes all existing records from the table before loading new data

- Use Case: Full refresh scenarios

3. Delete

- Deletes only records in the target that match incoming records (based on keys/conditions)

- Use Case: Targeted clean-up before loading updated records.

How to Create a Data Flow

Example: Persist Sales Transactions by combining them with Product and Store details.

Steps:

1. Go to Data Builder → Select Flows.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

2.Click New Data Flow

 

3. In the canvas:

    - From the HANA_CLOUD connection → navigate to the TECHED folder

    - Drag and drop Sales_Transactions123, Product, and Stores tables

 

4. Perform the joins:

    - Join Sales_Transactions with Stores on Store_ID

    - Join Sales_Transactions with Product on Product_ID

       4a.  Add the target table:

    - Click the output node → give a name

    - Choose “Create and Deploy Table”

5. Save and Deploy the data flow

6. Click Run to execute the flow

 

7. We can use the schedule option to run it on predefined intervals and monitor the execution using Data Integration Monitor or Data Flow Monitor.

Custom Python Step in a Data Flow

For simple filters and aggregation we can use the filter and calculated columns functionalities available graphically. For more advanced complex data transformations involving conditional logic, string parsing, KPI buckets we can make use of script operator. 

Let’s embed a Simple Python script inside the above Data Flow to calculate few KPI’s.

Steps:

1. I have copied the above data flow and created a new one with script operator. Insert the script operator after J_PRODUCT node.

     

2. Edit the Script Node and paste the below code:

Note: We need not use import pandas in Datasphere. It's already available internally.

def transform(data):

    df = data.copy()

 

    epsilon = 1e-9

 

    df['profit_margin'] = df['Profit'] / (df['Revenue'] + epsilon) * 100

    df['discount_rate'] = df['Discount'] / (df['Revenue'] + epsilon) * 100

    df['cost_to_revenue'] = df['Cost'] / (df['Revenue'] + epsilon) * 100

 

    df['high_discount_flag'] = df['discount_rate'] > 20

 

    df['profit_category'] = df['profit_margin'].apply(

        lambda x: 'High' if x > 30 else ('Medium' if x > 10 else 'Low')

    )

    return df

```

3. Create new columns for all the above calculated values. 

4. Add the target table. Create and deploy the table.

5. Save and deploy the data flow.

6. Execute the flow — you’ll see the KPI’s populated in the output.

Input Parameters in Data Flow

We can create input parameters to dynamically populate the values entered by the user which can be used in filters and calculated columns.

1. Click on blank space in the canvas editor and click on input parameters from the details pane.

2. Create a new input parameter IP_STORE_ID with type string.

 

3. I have inserted a projection node between the J_PRODUCT node and script node. We can create filters, calculated columns in projection node. I have defined the below filter condition that uses the input parameter we just created. 

 

4. Save and deploy the data flow.  Once you run the dataflow it will prompt to enter the input parameter.

 

5. It’s running with ST9 as store ID.

 

Schedule

Schedule is used to run the dataflow on a recurrent basis similar to process chain batch loads. To run recurring scheduled tasks on your behalf, we need to authorize the job scheduling component.We can also authorize from your profile settings page.

1. Click on Create from Schedule drop down option. Click on Authorize.

 

 

2. I have scheduled it to run at 12.30 PM UTC.

 3.  In the Data integration monitor we can see it is scheduled to run every day.

Conclusion

This blog introduced the Data Flow feature in SAP Datasphere, highlights how it differs from other flow types, and explains key concepts such as update modes. It also walks through both standard and Python-based examples, covering input parameters and scheduling options.

entry.title: What’s Next for SAP Access Control 12.0?
entry.content:
What’s Next for SAP Access Control 12.0? This is one of the common questions to most of the Organizations, Leaders, IT Directors, Managers, SMEs, Consultants and Vendors who are currently using IAM solution - SAP Access Control 12.0 on any Data Base (Non-HANA DB or HANA DB).

First let’s explore the possible applicable scenarios of the Organizations who are using SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 solution.

  1. Hub Model on HANA DB: SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 on standalone SAP NetWeaver system on HANA Database, connected side-by-side with SAP S/4HANA, ECC, ECP, SuccessFactors or other ABAP systems.
  2. Hub Model on Non-HANA DB: SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 on standalone SAP NetWeaver system on Oracle, MYSQL or another non-HANA database and connected side-by-side with SAP S/4HANA, ECC, SAP ECP, SuccessFactors or other ABAP systems.
  3. Embedded Model on HANA DB: SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 installed on business systems (SAP S/4HANA or SAP ECC etc.) running on HANA database.
  4. Embedded Model on Non-HANA DB: Embedded Model - SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 installed on business systems (SAP ECC, etc.) running on a non-HANA database.

As SAP continues its strategic pivot toward cloud-first solutions, many Organizations using On-Prem SAP Access Control are asking: What’s next? With SAP Access Control 12.0 nearing the end of its innovation cycle and the emergence of new GRC platforms, it’s time to evaluate the future roadmap and available options.

SAP has announced that it will sunset innovation for GRC 12.0, however SAP Access Control and GRC solutions for SAP are NOT end-of-life! SAP is actively developing a next-generation GRC platform: SAP GRC Edition for SAP HANA, expected in Q1 2026. Along with SAP also has cloud-based product called SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (IAG).

Also, the existing SAP Access Control 12.0 mainstream support ends by 2027 and extended support ends by 2030.

For more information, refer to SAP Product Availability Matrix

For compatibility of SAP Access Control 12.0 with all the target on-premise SAP Applications, please refer to KBA: 1352498 - Support Pack Numbering - GRC Access Control

Now let’s explore the possible upgrade/migrate/future roadmap options in SAP for existing Organizations who are using SAP Access Control 12.0 solution.

Option 1: Upgrade to SAP GRC for HANA 2026

SAP GRC for HANA 2026 is a new version (not a new product) for any SAP GRC on HANA Organizations. This 2026 release is planned for both on-premises and private cloud deployments. Organizations wanting to stay on-prem or private cloud with long-term GRC needs and have existing /future needs of other SAP GRC modules like SAP Process Control or SAP Risk Management can upgrade to this.

Image Source: SAP

For more information, refer to

  1. SAP GRC FOR HANA, 2026* (*current working title)
  2. Understanding SAP’s Product Strategy for Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) Solutions

SAP GRC for HANA 2026 requires below 2 prerequisites

  • SAP NetWeaver should be minimum SAP S/4HANA Foundation. S/4HANA Foundation is just an upgraded version for SAP NetWeaver. This is not SAP S/4HANA full version. Organizations who are using SAP Fiori 2.0 would have already migrated their SAP NetWeaver to SAP S/4HANA Foundation. Incase if you are having lower version of GRC Support pack or still on Fiori 1.0 or using SAP NetWeaver as a base component for SAP GRC, then this is a mandatory step.  In case for an Embedded GRC model, SAP GRC for HANA 2026 can be installed on S4Core.
  • Databased as HANA DB: As HANA 2026 only supports SAP HANA DB, Organizations are forced to migrate their Non-HANA Database to HANA DB.

Organizations can choose the “Hub Model” or “Embedded Model” for their SAP GRC for HANA 2026 upgrade/migration.  In case if an existing Hub Model setup customer wants to move to Embedded model, it is like a new implementation of SAP GRC for HANA 2026 but can reuse existing GRC design.   

How to Migrate to SAP GRC for HANA 2026 from SAP GRC Access Control 12.0?

Once the above prerequisites are complete, SAP Access Control 12.0 can be upgraded to SAP GRC for HANA 2026 release as part of their standard maintenance program, meaning no new SKU or additional purchase is required.

End-of-maintenance (EOM) dates for the 2026 version will be updated to align with HANA EOM dates, extending support until 2040.

Option 2: Migrate to SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (IAG) – Standard Edition

SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (IAG), a cloud-based solution designed to manage and govern user access across SAP and non-SAP systems. It's part of SAP’s broader GRC (Governance, Risk, and Compliance) strategy and is hosted on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). It can be considered as cloud Access Control in layman terms. It is best for Cloud-first organizations or those adopting SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

This is ideal for the customer who are looking for a standalone cloud governance solution with full lifecycle capabilities.

In case if an existing SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 customer wants to move to Cloud IAG solution, it is like a new implementation of SAP Cloud IAG with reference to existing GRC design.

  • With SAP Cloud IAG Standard Edition, customer can integrate to Cloud system like SAP S/4HANA Public cloud, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba etc.
  • With Cloud Connector, custom can integrate to On-Prem system like SAP S/4HANA (On-Prem), SAP ECC and other On-Prem systems.

Similar Access Control features, SAP Cloud IAG offers below features:

  • Access Analysis: Real-time insights into user access to detect violations and risks. This is like Access Risk Analysis (ARA).
  • Role Design: Create and optimize business roles for cloud and on-premises systems. This is like Business Role Management (BRM)
  • Access Request: Self-service access provisioning for users across systems. This is like Access Request Management (ARM).
  • Access Certification: Periodic reviews and certifications of user access. This is like User Access Review (UAR) or other certifications reviews.
  • Privileged Access Management: Emergency access handling and monitoring for sensitive operations. This is like Emergency Access Management (EAM).

Will be creating a new blog on “SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (IAG) with different options, Pros and Cons, possible options”, stay tuned for this.

Option 3: Stay on SAP Access Control 12.0 (Short-Term)

Staying on SAP Access Control 12.0 isn’t a long-term strategy, but it’s a valid short-term option for organizations that need more time to prepare.  As SAP prepares to sunset support for Access Control 12.0 by December 31, 2027 (extended support runs until 2030), many Organizations are evaluating their next move. While cloud-first strategies and the upcoming SAP GRC Edition for HANA (2026) are gaining momentum, some organizations may choose to stay on Access Control 12.0—at least for now so Organizations can get more time for budgeting, complex landscape planning, or team training.

For organizations with complex landscapes, regulatory constraints, or budgetary limitations, staying on Access Control 12.0 offers a stable, compliant, and familiar environment while they prepare for the future. Meanwhile, Organizations can prepare internal teams for the shift to SAP GRC for HANA or SAP Cloud IAG.

In case if an existing SAP GRC Access Control 12.0 customer wants to connect to Cloud systems using Access Control 12.0, SAP Cloud IAG – Integration Edition can be used,

  • SAP Cloud IAG – Integration Edition is a specialized deployment model designed to extend SAP Access Control (on-premise) to manage access governance for cloud applications also like SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Ariba, SAP SuccessFactors etc.
  • It uses the IAG Bridge to connect your existing Access Control system to SAP Cloud IAG, enabling centralized governance across hybrid landscapes.
  • Like SAP Cloud IAG standard edition, SAP Cloud IAG Integration offers Access Control features, however this has limited features than Standard Edition. For example, PAM and Access Certification features are available with Integration Edition. Use IAG Bridge now, then migrate to unified GRC 2026 platform for future-proofing.

#

Scenario

Recommended Solution

Why It Works

1

Long-term on-prem/private-cloud GRC modernization

SAP GRC for HANA 2026

Unified, AI-powered platform; support to 2040

2

Cloud-first strategy (SAP RISE, SuccessFactors, Ariba, etc.)

SAP Cloud IAG – Standard Edition

End-to-end cloud governance with full lifecycle capabilities

3

Using SAP Access Control 12.0. Hybrid landscape with both cloud and on-premises systems

Short-term: IAG Integration Edition
Long-term: GRC for HANA 2026

Leverage current investment, add cloud governance, buy time

Summary

  • Option 1: Upgrade to SAP GRC for HANA 2026
    Ideal for on-premise or private-cloud customers using multiple GRC modules. Also with complex landscape, heavy customization and workflows. Provides a unified, AI-powered platform on SAP HANA with support extended to 2040.
  • Option 2: Migrate to SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance (IAG)
    Suits cloud-first organizations on RISE, S/4HANA Cloud, SuccessFactors, Ariba, or other BTP scenarios. Delivers full lifecycle access governance across SAP and non-SAP systems.
  • Option 3: Stay on SAP Access Control 12.0 (Short-Term)
    Gives organizations extra time for budgeting, complex landscape planning, and team training. Pair Access Control 12.0 with IAG Integration Edition and the IAG Bridge for hybrid visibility.

Conclusion

Choosing the right path from SAP Access Control 12.0 depends on your organization’s strategy, timeline, and risk profile. If you’re committed to on-premise GRC and need long-term stability, upgrading to GRC for HANA 2026 keeps you covered through 2040. For those accelerating cloud adoption, migrating to SAP Cloud IAG delivers a scalable, unified governance experience with less customization options than on-premise. And if you need breathing room to prepare, extending Access Control 12.0 in the short term—combined with IAG Integration—offers continuity without sacrificing compliance.

Whichever route you take, start by mapping your current landscape, aligning stakeholders on priorities, and building a clear project roadmap. Weigh the long-term benefits against immediate constraints to make an informed decision that drives both security and innovation.

What option works best for your organization? Tell us your GRC challenge in the comments. Like this post if it helped and subscribe for more SAP GRC blogs, news, tips!

SAP Access Control SAP Access Control for SAP S/4HANA  SAP Cloud Identity Access Governance

entry.title: Simplifying Attachment Downloads in RAP with CDS Views: A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
In a recent project, I faced a requirement where we had to allow users to download a file generated dynamically during runtime. The tricky part was that we were working within RAP and wanted to avoid any heavy coding and also it has to be dynamic. The reason it needs to be dynamic is that we need to access the stored file through the conventional ABAP API, which restricts us from directly accessing it in the CDS view.

In this blog, I thought to share my experience that how we achieved it with no UI coding and using the conventional Flight Schedule Details example.

 

Why This Approach?

When we were analyzing the requirement to achieve the download of the file through the service, We evaluated a few approaches - one using an extra service entity just for file streaming, and another directly embedding the logic into the existing root view. Will explain it in detail in a separate blog about the first approach,  and in this blog, will share the approach(second) that we finally chose. Reasons to choose the second approach:

  • We were able to achieve the download of the attachment with changes in the existing entity itself.

  • It requires no UI coding.

  • Achieved with less effort, as the attachment file and its connection link can be exposed through attributes and mapping with annotation.

 

How Does It Look in Action?

 

Diagrammatic Representation of the CDS Stack and Object Involved:

 

Ideally, the best practice is that the C view in RAP is built on top of the R view. However, for ease of structuring in this example, I have consumed the C view directly from the I view.

 

Interface View (ZI_SpFlightSchedule):

As with every RAP based structuring, we start with a root interface view exposing base flight data. While the dynamic selection of ConnectionLink, MimeType, and Filename can be implemented based on entity keys and logic, we have hardcoded these fields here for simplicity and clarity in demonstrating the attachment download concept.

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
@EndUserText.label: 'Flight Schedule with Download Link'

define root view entity ZI_SpFlightSchedule
  as select from spfli
{
    key carrid,
    key connid,
        cityfrom,
        cityto,

    'http://localhost:60518/testclient/sap/opu/odata/sap/ZSB_SPFLIGHTSCHEDULE_V2/ZC_SpFlightSchedule(carrid=''AA'',connid=''17'')/$value'
        as ConnectionLink,

    'application/text' as MimeType,
    'Flight_Details.txt' as Filename
}

Let me share my understanding of each attribute:

  • ConnectionLink:
    A URL field in your CDS view providing the download link for the attachment associated with the RAP entity. It is used for clickable navigation or API-based download of the attachment.

  • MimeType:
    Specifies the MIME type (file type) of the attachment to inform the browser or consumer how to handle the downloaded content (e.g., application/text, application/pdf).

  • Filename:
    Defines the default name of the file when the attachment is downloaded, ensuring consistent naming for users (e.g., Flight_Details.txt, Flight_Details.json).

     

Consumption View (ZC_SpFlightSchedule):

Now, Let's go for creation the  RAP transactional consumption view.

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Flight data'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
//@Search.searchable: true
@ObjectModel: {
    semanticKey: [ 'carrid', 'connid' ],
    usageType:{
        serviceQuality: #C,
        sizeCategory: #S,
        dataClass: #MIXED
    }
}
@VDM.viewType:#CONSUMPTION
@VDM.usage.type: [ #TRANSACTIONAL_PROCESSING_SERVICE ]

define root view entity ZC_SpFlightSchedule
  provider contract transactional_query
  as projection on ZI_SpFlightSchedule
{
    key carrid,
    key connid,
    cityfrom,
    cityto,
    ConnectionLink,

    @Semantics.largeObject: {
        mimeType: 'MimeType',
        fileName: 'Filename',
        contentDispositionPreference: #ATTACHMENT
    }
    @ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy: 'ABAP: ZCL_FOR_VIRTUAL_ELEMENTS'
    @EndUserText.label: 'Attachment'
    virtual Attachment : abap.rawstring(3056),

    @Semantics.mimeType: true
    MimeType,
    Filename 
}

Here the Attachment virtual element is linked with the attributes to know the properties for the file download.

  • MimeType for MIME type resolution.

  • Filename for correct naming.

  • contentDispositionPreference: #ATTACHMENT to force download instead of browser preview.

  • @ObjectModel.virtualElementCalculatedBy indicates runtime content population by ABAP class ZCL_FOR_VIRTUAL_ELEMENTS.

here it's not necessary to mention the length of the data type like virtual Attachment : abap.rawstring(3056), as this does not restrict or impact performance or storage limits. However, to indicate the expected file size for readability/documentation, I have included it.

 
Also, one challenge I faced was handling large files. Although OData supports streaming, we had to test the performance of files over 1MB. During testing, some downloads triggered browser timeouts or inconsistent behavior. To address this, we decided to enforce a size limit through backend logic for now. In our scenario, there are also possibilities to split or paginate the file content, which is something I plan to explore further in the next phase.

Also when checking for the memory limit of the file download got to know that the theoretical maximum will be upto 2 GB, but as mentioned earlier the practical upload/download via OData may face:

  • Timeout issues for large files.

  • Memory limits in the app server.

  • Frontend limitations (browser limits, network).

 

Implement Virtual Element Logic:

Now let's move on to the implementation of the logic required for the  file download content. In the class ZCL_FOR_VIRTUAL_ELEMENTS, lets' add the interfaces IF_SADL_EXIT and
IF_SADL_EXIT_CALC_ELEMENT_READ. Then, Implement the method IF_SADL_EXIT_CALC_ELEMENT_READ~CALCULATE to dynamically populate Attachment with the content of the file in xstring data type.

This allows dynamic downloads for each RAP record seamlessly.

METHOD if_sadl_exit_calc_element_read~calculate.
DATA: lt_original_data TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ZC_SpFlightSchedule WITH DEFAULT KEY,
ls_original_data TYPE ZC_SpFlightSchedule,
lv_BUFFER  TYPE  xstring.

lt_original_data = CORRESPONDING #( it_original_data ).
ls_original_data = lt_original_data[ 1 ].
SELECT SINGLE * FROM spfli INTO @DATA(line)
      WHERE carrid = @ls_original_data-carrid AND connid = @ls_original_data-connid.

    DATA(lv_csv) = |CARRID,CONNID,CITYFROM,CITYTO{ cl_abap_char_utilities=>newline }|.
    lv_csv &&= |{ line-carrid },{ line-connid },{ line-cityfrom },{ line-cityto }{ cl_abap_char_utilities=>newline }|.

 CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_STRING_TO_XSTRING'
      EXPORTING
        text     = lv_csv
        mimetype = 'text/plain'
*       ENCODING =
      IMPORTING
        buffer   = lv_BUFFER
      EXCEPTIONS
        failed   = 1
        OTHERS   = 2.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
* Implement suitable error handling here
    ENDIF.

    TRY.
        lt_original_data[ 1 ]-attachment = lv_BUFFER.
        ##NO_HANDLER
      CATCH cx_sy_itab_line_not_found cx_dynamic_check.
    ENDTRY.

    ct_calculated_data = CORRESPONDING #( lt_original_data ).

ENDMETHOD.

 

Metadata Extension for UI Annotations:

To enable a mapping with the connection link and the attribute of the file, let's add a metadata extension.

@Metadata.layer: #CORE
@UI: {
  headerInfo: {
      typeName: 'Reconcile Draft Reports',
      typeNamePlural: 'Flight Schedules',
      title: { type: #STANDARD, value: 'carrid' }
  } 
}
annotate entity ZC_SpFlightSchedule
  with 
{
  @UI.facet: [
    {
      id: 'GeneralInfo',
      type: #IDENTIFICATION_REFERENCE,
      label: 'Flight Info',
      position: 10
    }
  ]

  @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 10 }]
  @UI.identification: [{ position: 10, label: 'Carrier ID', importance: #HIGH }]
    carrid;

  @UI.lineItem: [{ position: 30, label: 'Connection ID', type: #WITH_URL, url: 'ConnectionLink' }]
  @UI.identification: [{ position: 30, label: 'Connection ID', type: #WITH_URL, url: 'ConnectionLink' }]
    connid;

  @UI.identification: [{ position: 40, label: 'Departure City' }]
    cityfrom;

  @UI.identification: [{ position: 50, label: 'Arrival City' }]
    cityto;

  @UI.hidden: true
    ConnectionLink;

  @UI.hidden: true
    Attachment;

  @UI.hidden: true
    MimeType;

  @UI.hidden: true
    Filename;
}

In the metadata extension, the  @ui.lineItem and  @ui.identification annotations use: 

  • type: #WITH_URL
    This instructs Fiori Elements to render the field as a clickable hyperlink in the UI (List Report or Object Page), instead of displaying it as plain text.

  • url: 'ConnectionLink'
    This specifies which field in your entity contains the URL that should be used as the hyperlink target when the user clicks the displayed field (e.g., connid).

 

Service Definition and Binding:

Then finally, let's create and expose your RAP service definition and OData V4/V2 binding to allow consumption by Fiori Elements apps and testing.

 

Testing the created service in Swagger:

In RAP and OData, the $value segment is used to retrieve the raw binary or textual content of a property, often for streaming large objects like attachments.

In our scenario:

  • When the user clicks the ConnectionLink (which points to the RAP entity’s URL with / $value),

  • It triggers the RAP runtime to execute your virtual element logic,

  • Returning the attachment’s raw content for download using the MIME type and filename you defined.

    Example URL:/sap/opu/odata/sap/ZSB_SPFLIGHTSCHEDULE_V2/ZC_SpFlightSchedule(carrid='AA',connid='17')/$value

     

 

Happy Coding 😊

@M_Samiullah Regarding your question about Master Recipe and Master Inspection Characteristics (MIC). The support of MIC is partially already available within Public Cloud Edition since 2408.4. Currently only catalog related fields are missing. The support of these fields is planned with one of the next main releases.

For Private Cloud or On-Premises there are currently no plans visible that this object will be enhanced for MIC support as well. Esp. in PRIVATE releases below 2027 those structures are not available within function module PPH_MRC_RAP_BO_FACADE. Best will be here to request the enhancement with Customer Influence Program on PP area to get the function module and object being enhanced for an 2025 Feature Pack stack:
Link to CIP: https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/influence-adopt 

Put the request under application area for the business object, in that case the area that is responsible for master recipe. The data migration area is only responsible for the tools but not for the content (data migration objects). Responsibility to deliver data migration object capabilities is with the different application areas esp. as they are responsible for the APIs used within the content and here the API is lacking these structures.

entry.title: S/4HANA Private Cloud – Best-Practice for “Fixed Input – Variable Output” in Chemical Industry
entry.content: Customer Background The customer is a chemical company running S/4HANA Private Cloud. Their core process is a chemical reaction whose input quantities are fixed but whose output mix is uncertain (fixed feeding, diversified yield). The uncertainty is normal for the industry: the product is still saleable, yet every batch may differ in grade, purity, or by-product ratio, which changes the value of the yield. Current Pain Point Standard BOM / recipe configuration in S/4HANA assumes a fixed input-to-fixed output ratio. The customer cannot map the real-world “one formula in → many possible products/grades out” without manual work-arounds. Key asks (generalized): 1. System capability – Can S/4HANA natively handle “fixed input, variable output”? If not, what configuration or add-on is required? 2. Master-data model – How should the BOM/recipe and material masters be set up so the system proposes the correct co-/by-products and grades while locking the input quantity? 3. Operational flow – End-to-end process from planning to confirmation that captures the actual yield split and adjusts component consumption and cost accordingly. 4. Valuation & costing – Recommended method to allocate cost and value to each grade/by-product when the mix differs every batch. 5. SAP guidance & benchmarks – Official SAP best-practice documents / notes / Model Company content and any real customer examples we can reference.

entry.title: API to Delete GOS Attachment from Transaction Code & their Applications
entry.content:
Summary

This technical blog is subject to simplify process of attachment deletion and how best way it can be applicable to act as an API.

Introduction

We have come across multiple technical blogs on attachment( can be PDF, image or MS Office objects) in the specific T-Code of the Transactions, such as for Sales Order, Billing Invoice or other relevant business transactions.

Here we will focus on the business requirement to delete an already enclosed/attached one of the attachment  in the Inspection Lot(QA03) Transaction and methods of implementations.

The solution is bifurcated in the simple 3 steps and we will use a simple and straight standard class (CL_GOS_DOCUMENT_SERVICE) which will be generic to use for other transactions as well.

  • Step 1. Pass Object Types Object Key along with Doc ID
  • Step 2: Call DELETE_ATTACHMENT method of CL_GOS_DOCUMENT_SERVICE Class
  • Step 3: Commit and wait.

    Code Snippet will give a complete solution 

    ***************************************************************************************************

    ** Work area declare 

  DATA: LS_LPORB    TYPE SIBFLPORB,
        LS_LINK     TYPE OBL_S_LINK. 

DATA: LO_REF TYPE REF TO CL_GOS_DOCUMENT_SERVICE.

************************* Step 1 *************************************** 

** Value assignment

    LS_LPORB-INSTID = <Key Field> . "Pass Key field, in this case it can be Inspection Lot Number
    LS_LPORB-TYPEID = <Business Object>. "For Example 'BUS2045'Business Object of Inspection Lot
    LS_LPORB-CATID  = <Object Type>. " For Example'BO' Object Type
    LS_LINK-INSTID_B = <Doc ID>. “Pass Doc ID here

*********************** Step 2 *************************************

** Calling Standard Class   

CREATE OBJECT LO_REF.

  CALL METHOD LO_REF->DELETE_ATTACHMENT
    EXPORTING
      IS_LPORB      = IS_LPORB
      IP_ATTACHMENT = IS_LINK-INSTID_B.

*************************** Step 3 ******************************

  COMMIT WORK AND WAIT.

***************************************************************************************************

Application

Above Snippet can be fix in the below box, shows a simple Application approach interface with UI/BTP or any Non-SAP application sending request via any Interface or middle layer can be Odata service using SAP gateway using Client-Server response methodology. 

Simple above code snippet can be placed as part of API logic which will perform its deletion operation in the SAP Transactions such as Inspection Lot/Sales Order/Billing Invoice.

 

 

Conclusion

Deletion of attached document can be deleted by using simple standard class.

 

Will come up with another series technical developments around Inspection Lot.

entry.title: Custom Sales Blocklist in SAP Business One
entry.content:
Abstract

How can we block specific items for certain customers in SAP Business One? Unchecking the "Saleable" field in the Item Master Data will block the item for all customers, but what if we want to give clients the option to choose which items are not saleable for each customer during a specific period? The solution is to define a Sales Blocklist table in the system and use an SQL stored procedure to prevent sales forms from recording restricted data.

Steps

  1. User-Defined Tables – Setup
  2. User-Defined Fields – Management
  3. Modifying Stored Procedure in the Database
  4. Filling Out the Designated Table
  5. Sales Documents

1.  User-Defined Tables – Setup

To create tables in SAP Business One, follow this path and create the Sales Blocklist table:

Tools → Customization Tools → User-Defined Tables – Setup

💡For an auto-generated numeric key, set Object Type to No Object with Auto Increment; this automatically fills the Code column. Moreover, there would be no risk of duplicate keys and no need for custom numbering logic.

2.  User-Defined Fields – Management

To create columns in the User-Defined Fields Management form:

Tools → Customization Tools → User-Defined Fields – Management

💡After the table is saved, SAP Business One adds it to Tools → User-Defined Windows.

3.  Modifying Stored Procedure in the Database

Modify SBO_SP_TransactionNotification in the selected database.

IF _type = '17' AND @transaction_type IN ('A', 'U') -- Sales Order 
BEGIN
    DECLARE @CardCode NVARCHAR(50), @DocDate DATE
    DECLARE @BlockedItems NVARCHAR(MAX) = ''

    SELECT @CardCode = CardCode, @DocDate = DocDate FROM ORDR WHERE DocEntry = _of_cols_val_tab_del

    SELECT @BlockedItems = STRING_AGG(T0.ItemCode, ', ')
    FROM RDR1 T0
    INNER JOIN [@SALESBLOCKLIST] T1 
      ON T1.U_CustomerCode = @CardCode  
      AND T1.U_ItemCode = T0.ItemCode
    WHERE T0.DocEntry = _of_cols_val_tab_del
      AND @DocDate BETWEEN T1.U_FromDate AND T1.U_ToDate

    IF @BlockedItems IS NOT NULL AND @BlockedItems <> ''
    BEGIN
        SET  = 1001
        SET _message = N'Selling these items to this customer on this date is not allowed: ' + @BlockedItems
    END
END

  The code above applies the blocklist logic to Sales Orders. For the complete script, which extends this validation to other documents like Deliveries and A/R Invoices, please see the full version on GitHub.

4.  Filling Out the Designated Table

Fill the table manually or by copying data from Excel spreadsheets. Open the created table from the menu and fill it up for the specific restrictions.

 

5.   Sales Documents

In the following step, use a Sales documents like Sales Order by selecting a specific customer and items.

Now, when we select items for the specific customer that is on the Sales Blocklist table, we will see an error that forbids the user from selecting these items.

Conclusion

This method is a useful way to restrict the sale of specific items to certain customers for a defined period of time in SAP Business One. For the blocking logic itself, several alternatives can also be very effective. These include using the B1 Usability Package (a third-party add-on) or adding a User-Defined Field (UDF) at the row level with a Formatted Search for real-time validation. Additionally, for managing large volumes of restriction data, using the Data Transfer Workbench (DTW) for bulk uploads can be a useful tool for larger implementations.

 

Prepared by

Amirhossein Tonekaboni

SAP Business One ERP Consultant

  •   GitHub
  •   Linkedin
  •   Allmylinks

entry.title: SAP PP-MASTER DATA PART-1(MATERIAL MASTER AND BOM)
entry.content:
MASTER DATA

 In SAP, two types of data are created—master data and transaction data. 

Master data is static data that is used to drive key processes in the organization. Once the master data is created, it is seldom changed. Master data acts as a prerequisite to run business processes. 

Transaction data is dynamic data used to capture day-to-day business transactions. Master data is used during the creation of transactional data.

types of master data:

1.Material master

2.BOM(Bill of materials)

3.Work center

4.Routing

5.production version

 

1.MATERIAL MASTER:

->Material Master represents the central source for storing material specific data. It is used by all the SAP logistics components in the system.
 
->The material master contains information on all the materials that a company procures or produces, stores, and sells. It is the company's central source for retrieving material-specific data. This information is stored in individual material master records.
 
MATERIAL TYPES
 
Finished products (FERT): Produced in-house. 
 
Raw materials (ROH): Procured externally and then processed. 
 
Semi finished products (HALB): Products can be procured externally or manufactured in-house
 
 
INDUSTRIAL SECTOR:
 
Industry sector specifies the branch of industry to which the material is assigned. 
 
When you create a material master record, the industry sector you specify determines which screens appear and in what order & which industry-specific fields appear on the individual screens.
 
Following Industry sector are mainly used in SAP 
 
 Mechanical Engineering
 Chemical Industry
 Food & Related Products 
 Retail 
 Telecommunication 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 

 

2.BILL OF MATERIALS

 
A formally structured list of the components that make up a product or assembly.  The list contains the item number of each component, together with the quantity and unit of measure.

The data stored in a bill of material serves as a basis for activities such as:

. MRP 

. Production 

. Procurement

. Product costing

 

 

 

 

The highest low-level code (a code of 0) is attributed to the finished product assigned to the final product.

The second highest low-level code (1) is attributed to the finished product at the penultimate location , and so on. The system assigns low-level codes to the individual components at the different BOM levels in the same way. 

The system plans the products in the low-level code sequence, first planning the product with low-level code 0 and so on.

Conclusion:

Material master and BOM are two most core parts of Production planning as they affect the transaction data. Having a good knowledge on both is the first step towards understanding Production Planning.

entry.title: Breakdown Maintenance End to End Process
entry.content:
BREAKDOWN MAINTENANCE: -

                           In SAP S/4 HANA EAM the breakdown maintenance business process is a type of maintenance activity that will take place or be carried out in response to unexpected failure or breakdowns of equipment. In SAP S/4 HANA EAM breakdown maintenance will be carried out through the creation and execution of maintenance orders and maintenance notifications. In breakdown maintenance you correct a malfunction of equipment by raising the notification in the system. And then the work order will be performed by technician at the equipment and respective authorized person will approve the work order.

                              But the response to the breakdown maintenance should be very rapid because production will stop and due to this the manufacturing of finished material will be stopped and it will be a huge loss for any company.

Work process of breakdown maintenance: -

  1. Identification of breakdown: - here the notification will be created.
  2. Evaluation & Planning: - here evaluation of equipment, review the notification, based on the review they will assign priority, work order creation and also assign the work center or technician for the order.
  3. Execution of breakdown maintenance: -here execution of work order takes place, and the materials or spare parts will be procured from the inventory, equipment will be isolated, and it will be shutdown.
  4.  Documentation and data capture: - here the documentation and confirmation of work order takes place.
  5. Inspection and testing: - inspection and trail of equipment will be done after maintenance.
  6. Completion and reporting: - TECO – technical completion will be takes place in this step.
  7. Continuous improvement: - analysis of data will take place and the company will come up with improvements that need to be made.

STEP 1: -   CREATTION OF NOTIFICATION

We will create a notification through IW21 but here the notification type will be M2. Here M2 is being used because since it is malfunction of an equipment.

Here we will just enter the details of the functional location and equipment in the notification. We will provide the details to tell the technician that in particular location a equipment is present, and it needs to be repaired.
Functional location --> represents the location and equipment --> represents the machine

Here the details of the functional location and equipment will be provided and then after the technician will save the notification. If the equipment already has already existing notifications or else orders, then the object information key will display it in the format as shown below if it is being activated in the configuration path.

The production supervisor will inspect the equipment and then he will add the object parts that need to be inspected, and the damaged parts will be entered in the notification by navigating to the change mode of the notification.

   STEP2: - ADDING OF TASKS TO THE NOTIFICATION

Here after adding the tasks, we can be able to see the items and tasks in the next tabs of the notification. The tasks are being added because it indicated parts that might be damaged.

After entering all the details of object parts and damage in the notification the notification will be released or put in process by clicking on the green flag symbol which is present in the notification

Also, the production supervisor will put in the tasks that are needed to be performed by the technician who is coming for maintenance purposes that he has to perform the maintenance activates that what he needs to perform on the machine.

Here the tasks will also be released from the notification.

STEP 3: -   CREATION OF ORDER BASED ON NOTIFICATION
Here the production supervisor will create a maintenance order through IW34 based on notification and the details will be picked up from the notification itself. And also, here since it is breakdown so the indicator will be checked.

The estimated costs will be given by the maintenance team based upon the requirement of the material and the person resources. 
Here the operational hours to do the maintenance will be added to the operations and the no.of people or manpower that is being required to perform the maintenance is being calculated here. The work center will be given here and the activity type will be picked up from the work center. For the activity type the cost calculation is done in the transaction code KP26 which will be done by FICO team.

In components tab what are the materials that are needed to perform the maintenance are being entered. Here in item category L - Stock item is maintained since there is stock in the inventory. 

After entering the components and the operational hours we will directly put them in the process because it is breakdown. Since we are putting it in a direct process a printout will be taken and then right after the work starts.

STEP 3: - MIGO - Goods Issue Against Order. (Material Management people are responsible for this step)
Here the goods will be issued by the material management by using the t-code MIGO.
A prerequisite that the order needs to be released or else posting goods against the order cannot be done. 
Here just check the movement type whether it is 261- goods issue against the order or not.

STEP 4: -    CONFIRMATION OF ORDER
Here the goods will be posted towards the technician against the order and the technician will perform the maintenance order and then the confirmation will be done and here we will just check the checkboxes like final confirmations, clear reservations, no remaining work.
Final confirmation --> it means the technician have performed his work and no more confirmation can be done for that                                                         operation.
Clear Reservations --> it means if there is any reservation that is done against the order for material it will be cleared.
No remaining work --> the technician has completely done his work, and no more work is pending if the work is still pending then the checkbox will not be checked, and the field remaining work will be entered. 

STEP 5: -    TECO --> TECHNICAL CONFIRMATION
Here after performing the confirmation, the technical confirmation will be done in the order header level as well as in the notification level too by clicking on the confirmation of tasks in the tasks tab in the notification. For order by clicking on the race flag which is present in the order.

After performing TECO for the notification then we will perform TECO for order.

STEP 6: -   SETTLEMENT OF ORDER
After completion of the order the FICO team will do the settlement against the order in KO88.

Accounting document: - Below is the accounting documents for the order.

Controlling document: - Below is the controlling documents against the order.

After performing the settlement by fico team, we will just navigate tot the t-code IW32 which is change mode of the order and here we will just click on the complete business.


Here you can observe the status as close in the system status.

FLOW CHART: -

The flow chart of breakdown maintenance 




The above describes the process of handling breakdown maintenance. Feel free to provide any comments or suggestions.

Regards,
Neeraj.

entry.title: Use the Public API to Maintain Availability data for Workforce Person from Excel
entry.content:
⚠️Disclaimer: The script in this blog is provided as a reference to accelerate the bulk upload of availability data. This is not an official SAP product. For uploading availability data through resource management, refer to SAP documentation.

Overview

Recently, I worked on a requirement where we needed to upload workforce availability data into SAP Resource Management. After the workforce person replication was completed from the SAP Master Data Integration (MDI) service, I explored ways to efficiently maintain and update availability using Microsoft Excel and SAP’s public Workforce Availability API.

While SAP offers tools like the Maintain Availability Data app and Workforce Availability API, I wanted to simplify the process for non-technical users. So, I automated the upload process via Excel macros (VBA) — allowing anyone to upload workforce availability data without needing to write any code or use external tools like Postman or curl.

Here’s a breakdown of how I approached it, along with key steps and learnings.

Current Ways to Maintain Availability Data of a Workforce Person:  

Now, SAP gives you a couple of options:

  • Use the Maintain Availability Data app

  • Or use the Workforce Availability API.

We will use Microsoft Excel and the public API to upload the availability data of workforce person.

Requirements:

  • A Windows operating system
  • Microsoft Excel
  • This process will be working with the custom domain migration. For more information refer Custom Domain Documentation.

Setup/Configuration:

Follow the below steps to set the Excel ready to upload the availability data.

If the Developer tab is not enabled in Excel, follow the below steps. If it is already installed, skip this step.

Enable the Developer Ribbon in Excel
  1. Click on the File tab.
  2. Select Options.
  3. Click Customize Ribbon.
  4. Under Main Tabs, check the Developer checkbox.
  5. Click OK.

Once enabled, the Developer ribbon will be visible in the header section in the Excel.

Step1: Download the CSV Template

  1. Login to Resource Management and navigate to the Maintain Availability Data app.

  2. Download the required CSV template for the selected workforce person.
  3. Open the downloaded CSV file using Microsoft Excel.
Step 2: Import Files into VBA
  1. Click on the Developer ribbon.
  2. Select Visual Basic to open the VBA Editor.
  3. Download the files added in the Github URL  into a folder in your local System.
  4. In the left-hand panel, under VBAProject (Microsoft Excel Objects), right-click and select Import File.
  5. Import the provided .bas file.
  6. Repeat the same process to import the .frm file.
  7. After importing, the project structure will update with added modules and forms.

Step 3: Run the Macro Script
  1. Under the Modules folder in the VBA Project, locate the imported module file.
  2. Click on the file and select Run from the header.
  3. A pop-up confirmation will appear. Click Run.
Step 4: Provide Required Information
4.1 Starting API URL Format:
https://{host}.{domain}.{environment}/WorkforceAvailabilityService/v1
  • The host and environment are constant; the user only needs to provide the domain.
  • Domain options:
    • eu10 → eu10 datacenter 
    • us10 → us10 datacenter
    • eu11 → eu11 datacenter
4.2 Authentication Details
4.2.1 Creating a Service Key 

You should follow the steps mentioned here to create the service key to the access the public API.

  1. Open your Global Account in SAP BTP Cockpit.
  2. Open your Subaccount.
  3. In the navigation area, select Spaces and open the required space.
  4. Navigate to Services > Instances & Subscriptions.
  5. Locate the service instance for which you need to create the service key.
  6. Click on Actions (⋮) and select Create Service Key.
  7. In the New Service Key dialog :
    • Enter a name for the service key.
    • If using client credential authentication, no further input is needed.
4.2.2 Viewing Credentials
  1. Once the service key is created, select View Credentials.
  2. A JSON file is displayed containing the following key attributes:

Attribute Description

uaa.clientidThe OAuth client ID.
uaa.clientsecretThe OAuth client secret.
uaa.urlThe base URL for the OAuth server.
apiUrlThe base URL for resource management APIs.

These details can be used for authentication in API requests.

  1. Enter the values in the form that appears when running the script.
  2. Edit the authentication URL for the OAuth server by appending /oauth/token.

Note: "Image/data in the screenshots is from SAP internal systems, sample data, or demo systems. Any resemblance to real data is purely coincidental."

Step 5: Submit the Data
  1. After entering all necessary information, click Submit.
  2. A confirmation MsgBox will appear. Click OK.
  3. The API response will be recorded in the file:
    • If successful, the message "200 Availability Created" will appear.
    • If failed, the error response will be recorded in the corresponding row for review.
  4. For real-time execution logs, open the VBA macro script and press CTRL+G. A lower window will display API requests and responses.
Step 6: Save the Excel File
  • Once all availability data has been processed, save the file as an Excel Macro-Enabled Workbook (.xlsm) for future use.

 

Further information and resources

  • WorkforceAvailability API in SAP Business API Hub: https://api.sap.com/api/WorkforceAvailability/resource
  • Set up API access: https://help.sap.com/docs/PPRM_OD/a2ad92d065e04e8393d72cace620e0be/24b5d0bbc0c442a5a8d258f7c17cd393....
  • API documentation: Workforce Availability

entry.title: Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release – What’s New
entry.content:
The new 2508 release has just been made available and of course we would like to share with you the innovations delivered for Warehouse Management. You can find a comprehensive overview in the What’s New presentation. 

But let me already give you an overview on some of the release highlights within this blog. Let’s get started!

 

Core Function 

Enablement of Additional End-to-End Processes 

Following our Suite-First strategy, we consider it essential that Warehouse Management works with all scope items and process variations that are available within SAP – and as you might know, that is quite a lot. Therefore, I am happy to share that with this release we were able to release the enablement of six (!) additional end-to-end processes: 

  • Stock transfer with delivery (BME) in combination with transportation management 
  • Intercompany stock transfer returns (2TS) 
  • Intracompany stock transfer returns 
  • Customer returns for sales kits (5CX) 
  • In-house repair (3XK) - Send back to customer 
  • Just-in-time supply to customer (2EM) - Summarized JIT calls 

For all of these, the respective delivery can now be distributed to and processed in Warehouse Management. The selection of the delivery via the according reference documents is enabled, e.g. to select an outbound delivery based on the JIT reference. You’ll find more details on each of these in the linked What’s New presentation. 

Stock Removal Strategy for Direct Goods Movement Postings

In my view, this innovation is quite special, because it is different from the classical paradigm to always go via warehouse tasks when removing stock. Some customers asked for a very simplified way of posting the consumption for the components of their production orders. Instead of using one of the production integration patterns where you first stage the components to the production supply area and then post the consumption from there, the staging and consumption is done in just one step. This is achieved, by posting the consumption directly from the storage bin in the warehouse. The operator is then responsible to physically remove it from there and hand it over to production, but from a system perspective the stock is already consumed. To simplify this process, we have introduced a new button in the app “Post Goods Movement”, to run the stock determination and to thereby propose the storage bin from which the consumption can be posted.

Combined Picking in RF 

This feature has already been very popular in Private Cloud EWM and has now been asked for by many of our Public Cloud customers. The scenario is to have multiple outbound deliveries, all requesting the same product. A typical scenario would be e-commerce where many different end customers have ordered one piece of a certain product. Since a picking warehouse task is always created per outbound delivery order item, this would mean in this scenario, that multiple picking warehouse tasks are created, all requesting one piece of the same product from the same storage bin. Obviously, confirming those in RF on the mobile handheld device one-by-one is quite cumbersome for the warehouse operative and very inefficient. With this innovation, those quantities are now combined, summed up and displayed as just one pick in RF, while in the background, it is still individual warehouse tasks. To prevent a day-one impact, this feature must be activated in the configuration. 

Migration Object: Assign Storage Bin to Production Supply Area   

Even though this innovation is “just” a migration object, I am convinced that it is very important to many customers. When working with the Advanced Production Integration, it is mandatory to maintain the assignment of storage bins to the production supply area, including the staging behaviour for individual products. As some of our customers have thousands of products to be maintained here, it is essential that this maintenance can be simplified with a migration object.

Compare Stock with Inventory Management 

When using Warehouse Management, the stock is managed in the warehouse on individual storage bins, but the stock is also still managed in Inventory Management on storage location level. Warehouse Management is then the leading system in terms of stock management. All stock postings are done in Warehouse Management, but they always update Inventory Management. Therefore, the stock balance in Warehouse Management and Inventory Management is always in sync. In rare cases it can happen that deviations occur, for example because of rounding issues. Worst case, this can then lead to an error when trying to update Inventory Management from Warehouse Management. Therefore, we have released a new app to compare the stock in Warehouse Management with Inventory Management. If there are any differences, then this app allows to immediately correct these differences with an additional stock posting, correcting the stock in Inventory Management. 

 

Extensibility 

New CDS Views 

Same as with the last releases, we have again shipped additional CDS views, allowing customers to access the data they need to build their extensions. 

There is a new CDS view to access the storage bin data, thereby making one of the most central objects available. In addition, there are new CDS views available in the area of wave management, providing access to wave headers and wave items but also to settings such as wave templates and wave types. 

 

Integration 

Additions to the Warehouse Order and Task API 

With the Warehouse Order and Task API being one of the most central APIs in Warehouse Management, it has received some additions in this release: 

  • Merging multiple warehouse orders into one warehouse order 
  • Splitting warehouse tasks from an existing warehouse order 
  • A new parameter to prevent the full handling unit withdrawal during the confirmation of product warehouse tasks 

Additions to the Storage Bin API 

The Storage Bin API had been a read-only API so far but has now been enhanced with the following: 

  • Create storage bins 
  • Update storage bins 
  • Action to block storage bins 
  • Action to unblock storage bins 

 

FIND OUT MORE! 

This blog only pointed out some of the highlights of this release – you can find the full list of innovations in the What’s New presentation.

entry.title: Material Documents Overview app key features - S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Material Documents Overview (F1077) brings this same functionality than the Display Material Document list (MB51), but with a more intuitive interface, better navigation, and embedded analytics.

With this app, you can view material documents related to goods movements. It also allows you to display the associated purchase orders and sales orders for each document.

  • Improved performance – faster response times;
  • Better usability – cleaner and more intuitive interface;
  • Enhanced navigation and filtering capabilities;
  • Add attachments to the material document;
  • Determine forms of output for a material document, such as print output or electronic data interchange (EDI);
    • When you perform a stock movement , such as a transfer or a goods receipt — the system generates a material document. Depending on the system configuration (using Output Management), this document can trigger different types of outputs, such as:
  • Print output: for example, a physical form to be used in the warehouse
  • EDI: an electronic confirmation sent directly to an external partner
  • Email or PDF: automatic notifications or attachments sent to relevant users or departments.
    • In the Items section, we can select the row of material document item to view all the output management information – In this section you can Preview Goods Receipt Slip for example, with the right setup in the Output Parameter Determination app. Here we can see that there is an EDI configured in channel to this kind of document.
    • MMIM_MATDOC_GDSMVMT_ESO: For EDI there are no printer settings. An EDI-message has no form templates as attachment.

  • Share the material document using chat in Microsoft Teams or send Email;
  • Reverse or partially reverse a selected material document;
    • It's not possible to split a document within the app, so a partial reversal can only be applied to material documents that were posted with two or more separate line items. So let’s jump to the example to show  how  partial reverse works – first I post a good receipt with two line items and than, inside of the Material Documents Overview app, it's possible to reverse just one line.

  • Generate report from material documents with the summarize option;
    • The information displayed is editable, which means the content may not be fully trustable as an official document
    • The tool only allows us to copy all the data, but it doesn’t, for example, generate a PDF

  • Display the associated purchase orders and sales orders with the material documents;
  • Show the assigned valuation type for the split valuated material - So if a material has multiple valuation types, you can either filter by one or display all the assigned types

     

Useful links: 

  • https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F1077')/S35
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/7cc07e548af58e4ce10000000a4450e5.html?version=2508.500
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/924584d1ecc849efb0762f1ff319ba00.html?state=DRAFT&q=MMIM_MATDOC_GDSMVMT_ESOA
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/output-management-in-s-4hana/ba-p/13762541
